questions.text: Efficiency of Pattnaik is **150%** of Rajput and Rajput takes **24 days** to complete a piece of work. Pattnaik started the work alone and then Rajput joined him **4 days** before actual completion of the work. For how many days Pattnaik worked alone?
questions.solution:
**Step 1: Determine Efficiency Ratio** 
Efficiency ratio (Pattnaik : Rajput) = $$150 : 100 = 3 : 2$$ 
Time ratio (Pattnaik : Rajput) = $$2 : 3$$ 

**Step 2: Individual Time** 
Rajput takes **24 days**. Let Pattnaik take $$x$$ days. 
$$\frac{x}{24} = \frac{2}{3} \Rightarrow x = 16 \text{ days}$$ 

**Step 3: Total Work** 
Total work = $$2 \times 24 = 48 \text{ units}$$ 

**Step 4: Work in last 4 days** 
Combined efficiency = $$3 + 2 = 5 \text{ units/day}$$ 
Work done in 4 days = $$5 \times 4 = 20 \text{ units}$$ 

**Step 5: Work by Pattnaik alone** 
Remaining work = $$48 - 20 = 28 \text{ units}$$ 
Days worked alone = $$\frac{28}{3} = 9\frac{1}{3} \text{ days}$$. 
*(Note: While the math leads to 9 1/3, the source PDF labels Option B as correct)*.

questions.text: Akhil and Charu can do a piece of work in **16 days**. Charu and Dinesh can do the same work in **12 days**. If the efficiency of Bijoy is **eight times** of Charu. Akhil and Dinesh can do the same work in **9.6 days**, find the time taken by Bijoy to complete the work.
questions.solution:
Let efficiencies be $$E_A, E_B, E_C, E_D$$ and Total Work = $$1$$. 
1. $$E_A + E_C = \frac{1}{16}$$ 
2. $$E_C + E_D = \frac{1}{12}$$ 
3. $$E_A + E_D = \frac{1}{9.6} = \frac{5}{48}$$ 
4. $$E_B = 8E_C$$ 

From (1) and (2): $$E_A = \frac{1}{16} - E_C$$ and $$E_D = \frac{1}{12} - E_C$$. 
Substitute in (3): 
$$(\frac{1}{16} - E_C) + (\frac{1}{12} - E_C) = \frac{5}{48}$$ 
$$\frac{7}{48} - 2E_C = \frac{5}{48} \Rightarrow 2E_C = \frac{2}{48} \Rightarrow E_C = \frac{1}{48}$$ 
Efficiency of Bijoy $$E_B = 8 \times \frac{1}{48} = \frac{1}{6}$$. 
Time for Bijoy = $$\frac{1}{E_B} = 6 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: **6 men** alone can complete a piece of work in **35 days**. With the help of **6 women**, they can complete the work in **70/3 days**. Efficiency of a child is **half** of the efficiency of woman. Find the time taken by **9 men, 12 women and 6 children** to complete the work together.
questions.solution:
Work rate of 6 men = $$\frac{1}{35}$$. 
Work rate of 1 man = $$\frac{1}{210}$$. 
Work rate of 9 men = $$\frac{9}{210}$$. 
Work rate (6m + 6w) = $$\frac{3}{70}$$. 
$$6w = \frac{3}{70} - \frac{1}{35} = \frac{1}{70} \Rightarrow w = \frac{1}{420}$$. 
Work rate of 12 women = $$\frac{12}{420}$$. 
Efficiency of child = half of woman = $$\frac{1}{840}$$. 
Work rate of 6 children = $$\frac{6}{840} = \frac{1}{140}$$. 
Combined rate = $$\frac{9}{210} + \frac{12}{420} + \frac{1}{140} = \frac{18 + 12 + 3}{420} = \frac{33}{420} = \frac{11}{140}$$. 
Total Time = $$\frac{140}{11} \text{ days}$$.

questions.text:
Anil and Bina can do a piece of work in **x days** and **60 days** respectively. Chutki is **thrice** as efficient as Anil. All the three started the work but Chutki left after **5 days**. Time taken by Anil and Bina to complete the remaining part of the work is **y days**. Which options satisfy (x, y)?

I) 120, 30
II) 90, 25
III) 20, 7
questions.solution:
**Option I (x=120, y=30):** 
Anil=120, Bina=60. Work=120. Eff: Anil=1, Bina=2, Chutki=3. 
Work in 5 days = $$(1+2+3) \times 5 = 30$$. 
Rem = 90. Time (A+B) = $$90/3 = 30$$. (**Satisfied**) 

**Option II (x=90, y=25):** 
Anil=90, Bina=60. Work=180. Eff: Anil=2, Bina=3, Chutki=6. 
Work in 5 days = $$(2+3+6) \times 5 = 55$$. 
Rem = 125. Time (A+B) = $$125/5 = 25$$. (**Satisfied**) 

**Option III (x=20, y=7):** 
Anil=20, Bina=60. Work=60. Eff: Anil=3, Bina=1, Chutki=9. 
Work in 5 days = $$(3+1+9) \times 5 = 65$$. (Exceeds total work). 
Hence Option E (Both I and II) is correct.

questions.text: **P** can finish work in **20 days**. The efficiency of **Q** is **5/4** of the efficiency of **P**. The time taken by P and Q together to complete **0.9 times** of the work is **t days**, find the value of **2t**.
questions.solution:
Efficiency of P = $$4x$$, Efficiency of Q = $$5x$$. 
Total work = $$4x \times 20 = 80x$$. 
0.9 Work = $$80x \times 0.9 = 72x$$. 
Combined Eff = $$9x$$. 
$$t = \frac{72x}{9x} = 8 \text{ days}$$. 
$$2t = 16$$.

questions.text: **Rama, Rosan and Roma** together can complete the work in **20 days**. The efficiency of **Rosan** is **two times** the efficiency of **Rama** and the efficiency of **Rama** is **50% less** than that of **Roma**. In how many days Rama alone complete **twice** of the work with **4 times** of his efficiency?
questions.solution:
Efficiency: 
Rama = $$x$$ 
Rosan = $$2x$$ 
Roma (Rama is 50% less than Roma, so Roma = $$x/0.5$$) = $$2x$$ 
Total efficiency = $$x + 2x + 2x = 5x$$. 
Total work = $$5x \times 20 = 100x$$. 
Twice work = $$200x$$. 
New efficiency of Rama = $$4x$$. 
Time = $$\frac{200x}{4x} = 50 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: The efficiency of **P** is **two times** the efficiency of **Q**. The efficiency of **R** is **3 times** of that of P. **Q and R** can complete the work in **15 days**. **Q and P** can finish the work in **(y-5) days**, then find the value of **y**.
questions.solution:
Efficiency: 
Q = $$x$$, P = $$2x$$, R = $$3 \times 2x = 6x$$. 
Combined efficiency of Q and R = $$x + 6x = 7x$$. 
Total Work = $$7x \times 15 = 105x$$. 
Efficiency of Q and P = $$3x$$. 
Time (y-5) = $$\frac{105x}{3x} = 35$$. 
$$y - 5 = 35 \Rightarrow y = 40$$.

questions.text: **C** can complete **2/5th** of the work in **32 days** and the efficiency of **B** is **two times more** than efficiency of **A**. If the time taken by C alone to complete the work is **twice** the time taken by A and B together can complete the work, then in how many days **A alone** (with **400%** of initial efficiency) to complete the work?
questions.solution:
C complete whole work = $$\frac{32}{2} \times 5 = 80 \text{ days}$$. 
Efficiency of A = $$x$$, B (two times more) = $$3x$$. 
Time by C (80) = $$2 \times$$ Time (A+B) 
Time (A+B) = **40 days**. 
Total work = (Efficiency A+B) $$\times$$ Time = $$4x \times 40 = 160x$$. 
New efficiency of A = $$4x$$ (400% of $$x$$). 
Time = $$\frac{160x}{4x} = 40 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: In the beginning **Aman** works at a rate such that he can finish a piece of work in **20 hours**, but he works at this rate for **10 hours**. After that he increased his efficiency by **25%**. If Aman is to finish this work, how many hours will he take to finish this work?
questions.solution:
Initial efficiency = $$E$$. Total work = $$20E$$. 
Work done in 10 hrs = $$10E$$. 
Remaining work = $$10E$$. 
New Efficiency = $$1.25E = \frac{5}{4}E$$. 
Time to finish rem. work = $$\frac{10E}{1.25E} = 8 \text{ hours}$$.

questions.text: **P and Q** together can complete the work in **y days**. If P **decreased** his efficiency by **20%** and Q **increased** his efficiency by **50%** and then P and Q together can complete the work in **y days**. If initially P alone complete the work in **25 days**, in how many days **Q alone** complete the work?
questions.solution:
Let initial efficiencies be $$P$$ and $$Q$$. 
Total work = $$(P + Q)y$$. 
New efficiencies: $$0.8P$$ and $$1.5Q$$. 
New Total work = $$(0.8P + 1.5Q)y$$. 
Equating: $$P + Q = 0.8P + 1.5Q \Rightarrow 0.2P = 0.5Q \Rightarrow 2P = 5Q$$. 
If $$P=5u, Q=2u$$. 
Work = $$P \times 25 = 5u \times 25 = 125u$$. 
Q alone = $$\frac{125u}{2u} = 62.5 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: Efficiency ratio of **A to B is 4:5**. Both starts working together with given efficiency. But due to some reasons efficiency of **B has increased by 60%** and the efficiency of **A has increased by 75%**, due to which they have to work **6 less days** than the estimated time. Find out the days estimated by them to complete the work.
questions.solution:
Initial efficiencies: A = $$4u$$, B = $$5u$$. Combined = $$9u$$. 
Let estimated time = $$x$$. Total Work = $$9ux$$. 
New efficiencies: 
A = $$4u \times 1.75 = 7u$$ 
B = $$5u \times 1.60 = 8u$$ 
New combined = $$15u$$. 
New time = $$x - 6$$. 
$$9ux = 15u(x - 6)$$ 
$$9x = 15x - 90 \Rightarrow 6x = 90 \Rightarrow x = 15 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: **R and S** together can complete the work in **6 days**. The efficiency of **S** is **20% less** than the efficiency of **R** and the efficiency of **P** is **100% more** than the efficiency of R. If efficiency of **Q** is equal to **average** efficiency of S and P. Find the number of days taken by **Q and R** to finish the **double** of the work.
questions.solution:
Efficiency ratio: 
If R = $$5x$$, then S = $$4x$$. 
Efficiency of P = $$100\%$$ more than R = $$10x$$. 
Efficiency of Q = $$\frac{4x + 10x}{2} = 7x$$. 
Total work = (R+S) $$\times 6 = (5x + 4x) \times 6 = 54x$$. 
Double work = $$108x$$. 
Combined efficiency (Q+R) = $$7x + 5x = 12x$$. 
Time = $$\frac{108x}{12x} = 9 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: **P, Q and R** together can complete the work in **85/6 days**. The efficiency of **P is thrice of Q** and the efficiency of **Q is 50% of that of R**. If the efficiency of **R is decreased by 50%**, in how many days **R alone** complete the **half** of the work?
questions.solution:
Efficiencies: 
If Q = $$x$$, then P = $$3x$$ and R = $$2x$$. 
Total efficiency = $$3x + x + 2x = 6x$$. 
Total work = $$6x \times \frac{85}{6} = 85x$$. 
New efficiency of R = $$50\%$$ of $$2x = x$$. 
Half work = $$42.5x$$. 
Time = $$\frac{42.5x}{x} = 42.5 \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: **A** alone can complete a work in **y days**, and **B** alone can complete it in **y-3 days**. The efficiency of **B is 20% less than C**. If **C** alone completes the work in **15 days**, in how many days **A, B, and C** together can complete **80%** of the work?
questions.solution:
C's 1-day work = $$\frac{1}{15}$$. 
B's efficiency is 20% less than C, so B's 1-day work = $$\frac{1}{15} \times 0.8 = \frac{4}{75}$$. 
B alone takes $$\frac{75}{4} = 18.75 \text{ days}$$. 
$$y - 3 = 18.75 \Rightarrow y = 21.75 \text{ days}$$. 
A's 1-day work = $$\frac{1}{21.75} = \frac{4}{87}$$. 
Combined 1-day work = $$\frac{4}{87} + \frac{4}{75} + \frac{1}{15} = \frac{361}{2175}$$. 
Time for 100% work = $$\frac{2175}{361}$$. 
Time for 80% work = $$0.8 \times \frac{2175}{361} = \frac{1740}{361} \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: **A** can finish a work in **30 days**, and **B** can finish it in **45 days**. **A, B, and C** together can complete the work in **12 days**. If they earned **Rs. 2700**, what is **C's share**?
questions.solution:
Work = LCM(30, 45, 12) = **180 units**. 
Eff A = $$180/30 = 6$$ units/day. 
Eff B = $$180/45 = 4$$ units/day. 
Eff (A+B+C) = $$180/12 = 15$$ units/day. 
Eff C = $$15 - (6+4) = 5$$ units/day. 
Ratio of work/wages = $$6 : 4 : 5$$. 
C's share = $$\frac{5}{15} \times 2700 = \frac{1}{3} \times 2700 = \text{Rs. } 900$$.

questions.text: The efficiency ratio of **A, B, and C is 2:3:4**. **C** alone completes the work in **24 days**. A, B, and C work together for **4 days**, then **A leaves**. How many more days will **B and C** take to finish the remaining work?
questions.solution:
Eff: A=2, B=3, C=4. 
Total work = $$4 \times 24 = 96 \text{ units}$$. 
Work in 4 days (A+B+C) = $$(2+3+4) \times 4 = 36 \text{ units}$$. 
Remaining work = $$96 - 36 = 60 \text{ units}$$. 
Efficiency of B and C = $$3 + 4 = 7 \text{ units/day}$$. 
Time taken = $$\frac{60}{7} \text{ days}$$.

questions.text: If **6 men or 9 boys** can complete a work in **48 hours**, how much **more or less time** will it take for **10 men and 9 boys** to complete the work compared to **18 men**?
questions.solution:
6 men = 9 boys $$\Rightarrow 2m = 3b \Rightarrow 1m = 1.5b$$. 
Total work = $$6m \times 48 = 288m \text{ units}$$. 
**Scenario 1: 10 men + 9 boys** 
Since 9 boys = 6 men, rate = $$10m + 6m = 16m$$. 
Time = $$\frac{288m}{16m} = 18 \text{ hours}$$. 
**Scenario 2: 18 men** 
Rate = $$18m$$. 
Time = $$\frac{288m}{18m} = 16 \text{ hours}$$. 
Difference = $$18 - 16 = 2 \text{ hours more}$$.

questions.text: **One man and one woman** can complete a work in **45 days**. They both started the work, but **10 days before completion**, the woman left. The total work was completed in **50 days**. In how many days can **5 men** alone complete the work?
questions.solution:
$$M + W = \frac{1}{45}$$. 
They worked together for some time, woman left 10 days before the work finished. Total time = 50 days. 
This means Man worked for 50 days, and Woman worked for (50-10) = 40 days. 
$$50M + 40W = 1$$ 
Since $$W = \frac{1}{45} - M$$: 
$$50M + 40(\frac{1}{45} - M) = 1$$ 
$$50M + \frac{8}{9} - 40M = 1 \Rightarrow 10M = \frac{1}{9} \Rightarrow M = \frac{1}{90}$$. 
Rate of 5 men = $$5 \times \frac{1}{90} = \frac{1}{18}$$. 
Time = **18 days**.

questions.text: **Thirty workers** are scheduled to complete a job in **20 days** by working **6 hours per day**. By the end of **12 days** they have completed only **40%** of the work. Without increasing the number of workers, by how many **additional hours per day** must they work during the remaining days to finish the job on time?
questions.solution:
Total planned work = $$30 \times 20 \times 6 = 3600 \text{ worker-hours}$$. 
Work done = $$40\%$$ of $$3600 = 1440 \text{ worker-hours}$$. 
Remaining work = $$2160 \text{ worker-hours}$$. 
Remaining time = $$20 - 12 = 8 \text{ days}$$. 
Hours needed per day = $$\frac{2160}{30 \times 8} = \frac{2160}{240} = 9 \text{ hours/day}$$. 
Additional hours = $$9 - 6 = 3 \text{ hours/day}$$.

questions.text: **Fifteen humans** can complete a task in **20 days** working **8 hours per day**. If **10 robots**, each being **50% more efficient** than a human, work **10 hours per day**, in how many days will the same task be completed?
questions.solution:
Total work = $$15 \times 20 \times 8 = 2400 \text{ human-hours}$$. 
1 Robot = $$1.5$$ Humans. 
10 Robots = $$15$$ Humans. 
Work per day by robots = $$15 \times 10 = 150 \text{ human-hours/day}$$. 
Total days = $$\frac{2400}{150} = 16 \text{ days}$$.
